This place is very unlikely so close to La Paz but it was very interesting to see and the Age of the valley is impressive
Our group took a tour of the Valley of the Moon one afternoon and everyone loved it. The landscape is very unique and beautiful in a strange way. It's worth seeing if you're in La Paz.
Moon valley was nice itself to walk around. But the staff was so unwelcoming not letting us in around 4pm because the staff finishes at 6pm the lady at the office was very rude

Unique valley with sand sculptures carved by the wind and rain, the area is very similar to the Cappodocia region of Turkey. ** somewhat inaccessible. Washrooms and shops are down a flight of stairs.

An awesome natural wonder.... And source of exercise! One of the most impressive things is the sheer size. Until you get amongst it you don't get an idea of the scale. It's a mad place.... And I'm not joking about hide and seek either! Let your hair down and try it! You'll need

Its like standing in a desert with artistic sand expression - its truly god gifted natural formation. Littel away fro la Paz but certainly worth a visit.

A short escorted tour from downtown La Paz and I was wandering through this strange landscape, carved by the wind and rain over thousands of years in soaring temperatures . Worth a morning or afternoon if time permits while visiting La Paz.

If you visit La Paz city, please spend some time at Valle de la Luna and feel yourself as walking on the moon ;)
Amazing place. Fantastic views. Definitely worth a half day trip and with a tour group so you learn much more :)

It's a must when you are in La Paz. Amazing different a little bit tiring :) interesting geographic formations.

Went on a date here with my gal...wonderfully fun and relaxing and worth it. Easy to do in an afternoon and by yourself or with a group (even a big one).

Nice place to go although not exciting. Good to spend an hour if you have nothing else to do. We had it as part of our day tour.
Relaxing walking tour for families and friends. Awesome to take pictures of incredible sights. It really looks as if you are on the moon.

Pleasant walk among bazar scenery with boulder mounted on narrow clay and sand pinnacles. Very nice walk to take with a small group after a noon meal that can be enjoyed at a local café. Best to tie in with a tour of city. Not a hard walk at all once accustom to the altitude.

Just on the outskirts of La Paz there is a park called Valley of the Moon. You can get there by taxi and we are told they will wait up to one hour for you to explore for 80 bolivianos. We just took the hop on hop off bus and they let us out for 20 minutes to take photos. It was

It was our privilege to visit this area prior to our reluctant departure from La Paz. The rovk formations remind me a little of Bryce Canyon in Utah, USA. It is definitely worth an hour of your time when you are visiting La Paz

One of the attractions here in La Paz, an incredible set of naturally sculptured sand stone which has resulted in a surreal setting.
The place is not so atractive to me. But it's a good place to kill some times when you are free in La Paz since it takes around 40 minutes to get there. The place is well organized.

This place was very interesting to visit as the landscape is so different from the rest of the area around La Paz. The trails are easy to navigate and there are great views from here. There are also some little shops with that carry local crafts and art work here.

Went there with a small group and walked several of the paths. Very interesting rock formations easily accessed by several paths of differing difficulty, but none too hard. Some of the views were spectacular.

It is a great place to escape from the La Paz, something that you would not expect in the middle of such city. It is really good organized with city bus tour as it stops there for 20' so you can have time to enjoy it and then get back to the bus!
The valley is located just out side of La Paz. It has interesting rock formations. Takes a little less than an hour to hike through the site. If you have some free time it is worth a visit.
Nice place, but they have to learn how to became a touristic point the little roads must be fixed to be a great place

This very nice valley located just outside the city of La Paz is relatively small, but shows all the same traits of the Cappadocia valleys in Turkey, with unusual rock formations and amazing colours! Highly recommended if you're in the area!
Valle de la Luna is an area with unusual rock formations not far outside of La Paz. I spent about an hour there walking along the trails. It has interesting views all around.
After being in the city it was nice to get out into the open. Health and safety probably wouldn't pass it in the uk. There are quite a lot of places you could fall and the rails had seen better days.
Nice place in La Paz Bolivia to visit whith your family or friends,good view and good climate and environment.
Nice rock and earth formations to hike up and down. Very well displayed with different cactus plants spread all over.

This moon walk climb is very good.Very pretty site to climb walking enjoy the beauty.You must visit and spend and about an hour.

Valle de la Luna is a good place where you can see the other side of Bolivia. It is an interesting place because of the landscape. It is a leisurely place where you can do probably less than 2 hours to tour.
Fantastic, felt as though you are out of this world. well organized site and great visit. some hiking and hills, be ware.
Great outdoorsy experience, bring your tennis shoes to do the full climbing. The sightseeing is great and pretty different to what you normally get.

Cool valley located south of the city. There are two routes to take, one 15 minutes and one 45 minutes. Take the 45 minute route, but don't plan to stay much longer. A neat place to see, but 45 minutes is long enough.

When we went, it was quite. We didn't take a tour, we just wondered round. For anyone interested in geological landmarks, this is awesome. A cheap taxi ride out, and a fun way to kill an hour just outside la paz.
Amazing hike through incredible vistas. Bring a camera and a lunch. Good to spend the day and acclimatize when you first arrive in La Paz

This is a great area, so different to the rest of the natural environment we've seen. It is easy to get to by local transport and it is cheap.

Dried lake bed remainder after a natural dam burst leaving uniques structures Imagining it filled with water and scuba diving in it made it more interesting to me. Sort of like the bottom of a stalagmite cave with the top removed

Awesome. This is mis is it in La Paz

text.wiki:
The Witches' Market, also known as El Mercado de las Brujas and La Hechiceria, is a popular tourist attraction located in Cerro Cumbre, a mountain clearing in La Paz, Bolivia. Merchandise sold in The Witches' Market, run by local witch doctors known as yatiri, includes potions, dried frogs, medicinal plants like retama and armadillos used in Bolivian rituals. The yatiri can be easily identified by their black hats and coca pouches containing amulets, talismans and powders that ensure luck, beauty and fertility. Most famous of all the items sold in The Witches' Market are the dried llama fetuses. These llama fetuses are buried under the foundations of many Bolivian houses as a sacred offering to the goddess Pachamama.

It is a must see, but not very special. A set of stalls / shops. You can recognize them by the dead baby-lama’s hanging. They sell lots of powders and other stuff to be healthy, happy or whatever. It is not only for fun, the Bolivian people really rely on many items, for example

visit this place and it is very interesting, they sell a lot of typical crafts of the country and you can find everything for gifts and souvenirs, lots of natural plant to take, if you feel bad for the height. I highly recommend visiting this place within the city. Great

My girlfriend visited La Paz 5 years ago and was really disappointed with the Witches market this time round. They offer a huge variety of tourist aimed souvenirs at next to nothing prices which is obviously good. However, it’s more just market than ‘Witches’ market these days.

Great little area for browsing and learning about local traditions and mythology. The buildings and paved street have a certain ambience, but watch out for the cars that sneak through here too quickly.

Had a lovely ramble around. Quite breathless as we weren’t used to the altitude of La Paz, so took it easy going up the hill to get there. Bought some nice little gifts. Very colourful and wonderful for photos. We didn’t haggle, perhaps we should have, but really, things are so
Besides the "interesting" llama foetuses, most of the stalls sell the same stuff. Interesting for a walk, but too orientated to the occasional tourist to meet my personal taste.

I had great expectations for Mercado de las Brujas. I hoped it would be bigger. Nevertheless it was very interesting to visit it. I am 100% sure that people actually use that stuff, not only sell it for tourists.
The witches market has lots of tourist shops with all kinds of good priced items. You can see the traditional shops with alpaca babies en fetusses.

This is the place to come to have a concoction made to ward off, heal or bring good fortune for whatever you desire. There are dried llama fetuses hanging at the entrance of the shops which will supposedly bring you good luck when put into the foundation of the house you are

Great spot to go and a definite must-see destination if you head to La Paz. A lot of history in this area but also some great places to grab some small bites and plenty of places to buy gifts and things. Ended up buying a loooooooot of stuff

I didn´t know before going to the witches market that still people can buy offerings to worship ancient gods. Stuff for good luck, to attract love even black magic stuff can be found. Highly recommended if you want to see the believings of the people

Lots of stuff. Handicrafts, musical instruments, all down different streets / aisles. The witches area has lots of herbs, charms, and yes, dried up llama fetuses.
Combined with San Francisco and plaza Murillo, this is a classic must do day stroll in La Paz. Nice local gifts, folklore, and traditional curiosities.

Was expecting a bit more when we first walked through by ourselves. You can literally walk in and out of a shop in 2 mins. We then went through again with a walking tour and had the full spiel. Very interesting once you actually know what you’re looking at

Slightly gruesome yet fascinating view into local folklore. Worth walking through, part of the La Paz scene.

One of the must visit places in La Paz. This is a beautiful street with many weird things to see in the stores. Apart from that you can find cheap souvenirs in there.
This is an interesting street to walk down. We were able to pick up some fun and interesting knick knacks to take home for our friends.

It is small and feels geared mostly to tourists. I still enjoy seeing these things so I was happy to visit, but I was definitely not compelled to buy anything and struggled even to find good photos to take

.... although I wasn't sure about the Lama babies and fetuses. I hope they did not suffer. My girls could not look at them. But very interesting products they have in these stores.

I was really excited to see the Witches Market's in Bolivia, though I had thought they were up in El Alto. So I was interested when my husband googled and said they were right near the Coca Museum. Ummm...no, these aren't it. If you don't want to trek up to El Alto where you
I went to this market which is mainly two blocks with little shops that sell from herbs and magic potions, to beautiful handicrafts. Good way to interact and support locals.

Although the "brujas" are part of bolivian coulture, for foreiners, it sounds a little scary, specially when you see llamas fetos in front of the stores. But to get envolved with bolivian culture, it worth the visit!

The Witches market is a great place if you are looking for handcrafted goods in La Paz. Easy accessable too.

I was in La Paz in 2007 and I remember visiting the "Mercado de la Hechicería" back then. It wasn't a tourist attraction, just a couple of streets lined by shabby esoteric shops. But it was charming, exotic, and mysterious. I saw some women sitting on a low wall, waiting, and

Bolivian handicrafts are beautiful, this is a place to find at a more than reasonable price and you can compare from one store to the other in just one block, then you forget to buy souvenirs or gifts to relatives or friends...
Having traveled the world, many of these markets look the same. This is enough different to make it interesting. Worth seeing.

A few streets of stores that sell everything remotely witchy. Some store owners can speak English so they can give you a very good explanation of what each trinket is for. Overall very interesting if you wish to delve into the symbolism and rituals of the Bolivian people.

Having seen some disappointed reviews online about the market, we weren't sure what to expect. Yes, the vendors are mainly catering to tourists and yes, it is actually a littler smaller than expected. However, if you take the time to explore all the shops, alleyways and

My favourite place in La Paz was this whitch market. You can buy charms for every occasion and cures for every illness.... I really like the thought that a soap can help you find a job..... If everyone would belive it...
You can find a lot at very different prices ... negotiate it’s possible ! But you definitely DON’T need a guide ... it’s a market nothing else.

---But not one of a kind. It's definitely set up as a tourist attraction nowadays and is good for photo-ops. But just in case you miss this market, there are always opportunities to see the same knick knacks, and purchase hand-knit wools at every city in the altiplano.

This was a block from my hotel. I visited it on my first day and didn't think too much of it. I took a picture or two and moved on. Enjoy!!

We came here on our first evening in La Paz and we really liked the market. It was close to our accomodation so we went there lots of time. Its a Mix of creppy things, widges stuff, palisanto smell and of cause a lot of touristy stuff around. Its crowdy with Tourists in the

Definitely became a tourist destination with not much witches paraphernalia... it is OK because it is gross anyway.

This area was so cool. Tons of hand made trinkets, interesting "witches" herbs and remedies, alpaca garments, jewlery, etc.

Located in the narrow laneways , there are lots of amazing shops with the colourfully dressed owners , great place to take photos

The Market is located right downtown La Paz, so very easy to get to. The items for sale are very unique to Andean culture.

If you're not visiting the witches market, what else will you do in La Paz ? I agree with other reviewers that it does not meet all the hype, but it is worth strolling for an hour or so. Have a stiff drink after.

One of the best and more convenient places for your shopping in La Paz, if you are a tourist of course :-)

Definitely worth a visit to the witches market. Really interesting to see all the different medicines and offerings available to the pachamama. Be prepared for the baby llama bodies that are sold as offerings!!

The Witches' market is excellent . YES! There are so many shops to choose from with potions, herbs, remedies and concoctions made to suit your desires, wishes, intentions, etc. The fact that lama fetuses are sold as good luck and are clearly visible in the shop fronts is
Good place to buy bolivian souviniers for good price, easy to negociate and bargain. Lots of colorful souveniers

Nice place to walk and know, the most places sell handcrafts and local products but also you can find places where are sold products for witches or similar nothing to be afraid just products. Interesting place.
It was interesting as it it is unexpected and different. They have very weird products and some can be really stange if you are not prepared for it! Enjoy the difference!

Very special place, you may believe, or not, in witchcraft but here you will find everything needed to carry it on. Astounding how it is presented in a modern way, just as a pharmacy. Very peculiar place.
The witches market is smaller than I thought but the shopping that surrounds it is top notch. Boyfriends beware, you will spend a lot of time shopping ha ha
It's very interesting place, you must go see theses stores. You can take nice pictures. Don't mist it !!!

It’s worth a walk through but it is a bit hyped in my opinion. Vendor after vendor selling much the same thing—very touristy.
Standard market except for the rehydrated foetus of llama. But then we didn't have a guide pointing anything out so not sure if we missed something.
Probably one of the best places in La Paz to get souvenirs, the people are nice and the prices are reasonable. It gets very busy during the day.
Need ingredients for a witch doctor brew? Well, this is the place to go for bones, plants and, yes, dried animal foetuses. Worth a morning stroll, whether buying or not.

yes its probably more for "tourists" now but they still do have their potions and amulets and things to buy! its well worth walking around the area to get some things! nearby also the regular souvenir shops have fun with it and you will enjoy!
If you want to buy the typical souvenirs, I would recommend this for you. I don't think that there is much of a witches' market left. Its mostly just touristic stalls.
Weird stuff AF as dried llama fetus and spells. Worth seeing and buying coca leafs (coca leafs are NOT drug, its ancestral energetic ritual).
We enjoyed looking around the Witches Market .Very interesting and lots to see .We came nearly 5 years ago and now we back again this was the first place I wanted to visit to buy some handbags!!!

its a fun place to go although a little small in size. some of the stalls will go at length to explain the things they sell, but it helps, of course, to speak spanish!!!

So is probably the number one thing to do. It consists of a few streets and a lot of vendors selling the same wares. I guess we did see the llama fetuses, but one tires at the same stuff over and over again. We did not see any witches. In hindsight we should have bought more,

We did our souvenir shopping here and found great stuff! We got very interesting info about the market on the tour we did with the "red cap walking tours" (also here on trip advisor) - really recommendable!
This is right off of sagarnaga which is the biggest tourist hub of the city. Llama fetuses and fun/superstitious remedies. Interesting and quick to walk through. Not necessary to buy anything.

Lots to see and lots to shock from days gone by. If you don't have a stomach for witchcraft then dont go into the shops, some of it is funny though but there is still plenty of other stuff to see in the street.

There is no Mercado de las Brujas. Its just some ladies selling stuff like herbs and trinkets that Bolivians believe will help their health and or buying a house, a car, or stuff like that. There is no attraction but they make it sound like there is one to get you to pay a tour

The "Witches' Market" of La Paz sprawls over several blocks of one street, Calle de las Brujas. It has something fro everyone - tourist can find both cheap and expensive souvenirs. Locals can find Llama fetuses! eek! Cars drive up and down this very thin alleyway, so watch

We enjoyed browsing the numerous markets. Vendors were not as pushy as in some places. Bargaining is not so prevalent. It is a comfortable place to shop for gifts and souvenirs.

There are a lot of street vendors as wells as tons of stores. I found most of my souvenirs there (alpaca shawls and blankets). Great place and very convenient for shopping. Most everyone here is willing to barter prices. As touristy as it is, you still get a great authentic
Easy to get to, but it is a small street with few stores compared to other places in South America. Bit of a tourist trap.
