Near the cathedral San Francisco and the main tourist/handicraft area, this area sells items for traditional ceremonies (like the mesa. While not spectacular and very touristy, it is still a can't miss half and hour in La Paz.
It's a small market (about 3 or 4 stores), but the tradition behind them is what matters. Try speaking to the owners, and you'll find many interesting rituals.

This is absolutely one of the musts when you visit La Paz, Bolivia. It is an incredible market where you will learn about the Aymara traditions on the cult to Mother Earth, see all the types of offerings that are being done, amulets and much more. A definite must when you visit
If you love to look for interesting things, this is the place for you. The street has a great variety of stores and street vendors where you can buy good presents and souvenirs at a very good price.

The area has a huge amount of souvenir shops and certainly you find what you are looking for. The fact that dead animals (or part of it) are for sale is disgusting, as disgusting as going to the butcher. All meat eaters should not have any problems to be at the market. All

The location is within walk of Hotel Rosario and has all the shopping you could hope for we were warned of the dangers of La Paz but never felt in danger at all. There is so much to see from musical instruments ,storage items , Alpaca, old textiles, New trend alpaca designs. all
Great place to buy souvenirs and to see unusual things like llama foetus and magic potions. Some interesting finds and typical merchandise.

It is interesting walking through the street, though not something you need to spend much time doing. the interesting medicinal and religious items are also commonly found in everyday markets, so we weren't very surprised by the brujas market. Howover, this is located in the

Great area to shop for Bolivianite gem other tourist items. Be careful and be aware of pick pockets. Also be very aware of the traffic because they are not aware of you. Traffic in Bolivia is scary but interesting to experience. I wish the tour had allowed more shopping

Once you get there you start reading boxes like "miracle" ones, I rather don't point them out here because there will be no interest then to go and visit, just don't be surprised to see crazy things ;)

Central La Paz is a wonderful, vibrant, eclectic place. And part of this is the Witches Market. Bolivia is both deeply religious and superstitious. Which is reflected by the array of items on show. From skulls to smoking devices to numerous replicas of superstitious figures.

Im not sure exactly how this became an "attraction" but this is not a market, its just some kiosks on the side of the road. I dont even think there is 10 of them... maybe 6-8ish. This area in La Paz is looked down upon by all locals , and all the Bolivian people in general,
I was looking for a closed place with weird things but it is a street with stores. Mainly there are stores of souvenirs. Just found a few considered for witch.

I had walked around the Sagarnaga street for so much time searching for this "Mercado de las brujas" in Spanish. I had asked 5 or 6 units of locals and tourists, each pointing out quite different location and some don't know. Even the tourist map looks inaccurate either.
If you visit San Francisco Church,well then then, Witches a Market is only a 3 minute walk around the corner from there. Don't be too squeamish though!

I was expecting a large market but what this actually is, is a line of stalls on the street (maybe 8 - 10) much as you see everywhere else in La Paz. What makes this different are the products on sale. There is coca leaves and teas, all kinds of herbs, amulets for every
Wander round this safe area and pick up a gift or two - from coco leaves to small carvings. The ladies are helpful. I purchase some ointment and still here to tell the tale.

It is really nice and entertaining. Bring cash to buy souvenirs. Don't make jokes in any language about what you see, it's a different culture and it's necessary to respect it. The witches might help you with any wish you need to come true. Ask around!

You can find all sorts of odd herbal medicine here. I had no idea what any of this was which is probably a good thing as I found the dead llamas disturbing. This place seems very touristy I did not see any locals shopping here. Worth a visit if you are in the area but I
It is actually a very touristy place but the ambiance is really nice. You will find different local handcrafted items at affordable prices.
You will find all kinds of medicin, trinkets and souvenirs. If you haven't had time to buy alpaca clothes, you can do it here too.

The marked was a little disappointing to be honest. Only a few of the shops sold some peculiar things that can be associated with witches. The rest of it was typical tourist things (that you can find anywhere in Bolivia). I still had a good time though, and the marked should
Many tourists, shop owners beckoning for us to enter. Much better markets (admittedly not selling goods quite so unique) elsewhere in La Paz.

This place is horrible! Okay; if you like cheap stuff guess it is great. But there are dead baby llamas and embryos everywhere. Suppose to be a gift to Mother Earth, but i think it is horrible. In every shop, there are about 4 to 8 dead animals hanging there. It is disgusting
Much more expensive then other markets, completely built for tourist. You don't see a local buying nothing there. But don't go to la Paz without visiting it.

A good and safety place to buy a lot of souvenirs, sometimes could be hard to bargain, but walk around, if somebody was not friendly, go to another shop and ask (you won't die if won't try a discount).

The Witches Market is a must see for first-timers to La Paz. You can find quite of variety of things here from touristy souvenirs to bizarre items such a dried llama fetuses. One thing is for sure, this is a very fun and colorful place to visit when you are in La Paz. There

This basically is a shopping street with one "shaman/witches'" establishment. It is worth strolling the area if only for the people watching aspects. Prices are generally reasonable, and there is some interesting jewelry. Unless you are an avid shopper, this will not take a

An interesting place to visit, especially you can see the customs of the first Bolivians. Especially the recognition of Mother Earth, for who is offered all these artifacts. It is a mixture of religious and pagan belief for those who want to get an idea of the Andean spirits
You must go there and buy some rare presents and take pictures, the street is not safe but i recomend to take a city tour with an agency

This was on the top of my list for Lima and it was interesting enough with weird and disgusting things on offer but it was far smaller than I had imagined and all the stalls were basically the same. So worth a visit for the interest but don't plan to spend ages there!
Thought it would be more interesting than it really was. The shops are all over the place and besides some 'dried' baby alpaca's nothing crazy is going on.
The witch market is really interesting and offers a lot of weird but funny things to by. As it is in the Center you can do it within little time.

After hearing so much about the Witches Market this was disappointing for me. Yes, there were several shops displaying dead llamas - from fetus (not really sure how small that would be - they were all fully formed, just minature, leading me to wonder if they were real) to 2 feet

Beautiful handmade everything... I bought customer made leather shoes & jackets...so may beautiful things. Haggle haggle. You'll get great prices. Oh wear flats. It's all uphill I advice to start up top & work your way down. A must.
This is a street you will be taken by your guide on your city tour.You can buy local products around here.You can walk for a few minutes around here.
This witches Market or street is quite different. Worth the visit and walk .You will be taken here by the guide in your city tour.
Women at stalls did not know about using catalyst with coca leaves! Not as good as witches market in Lima.

Not sure if it was in full swing as we went on a Sunday. Interesting to see some of the shops, but also conscious that don't want to be there just to look and stare as the locals still believe in these traditions.

Mercado de La Brujas is quite a different market. With lots of bric/brac and things to give you luck, it a place to buy little trinkets that would make you feel better (if you believe in this stuff, but no harm). The lady who sold me the coca tea and anis tea said the that tea

Not really a market as such. A line of shops with some interesting things and trinkets to buy. Stuff you will not see anywhere else like charms to ward away evil spirits, etc. Definitely worth a look if you are in the area.
Lots of crafts here, but an unexpected find were the musical instrument stores. A great place to purchase a guitar or the typical Bolivian charango, not the souvenir type , but the real thing!!!
You'll have a very colorful view of La Paz on these streets. Don't let the name fool you, most of the witch's stuff is just for show. It's worth passing by.
Close to the centre of the town ıs the Witches Market where you can buy all sorts of talismans and potions. Several of the buyers were only missing thee costumes but none the less a great attraction
A fun, compact market with things you probably won't find in other markets, like llama fetuses. A good place to go shopping for souvenirs and other trinkets to bring back home.

We didnt walk through the market until late in the evening, but there was a lot of interesting stuff to see. Be warned, getting there involves steep hills. If you are not up for climbing up steep stairs, plan to take a cab and get let off as close as possible.

Be careful not to lose yourself for the entire day here! We set out just to buy a few gifts for family and friends and after haggling prices every few steps we quickly lost most of the day! If you're heading away from the beginning of the market, you cross a road that splits it

Interesting place to visit with some weird items for sale. In the market for llama fetus? This is the place to shop. Need some good luck amulets? Go no further. But we did find a certain sameness after visiting several of the stores. Prices are low and the vendors are not

This market is quite different from anything we have seen, so althought its really just few stalls along the street, I am glad we got the chance to visit. Where else would you be able to see the lama fetuses being sold, right?

A few street of unique shops from traditional herbal remedies to souvenirs to the Witch doctor places. We went into one and the lady in broken English was very engaging and prices were very low. Everything from shrunken alpaca fetus to dried things we did not want to know

If you are in La Paz, do find time to visit the Witches Market. As others have noted, you'll come face to face with llama fetuses which can be a bit unnerving the first time. But to be honest, we found a certain sameness and repetitive feel after visiting several shops. Many
delightful fun, enertaining and interesting. The sight, the sounds, the smells, the experience, it was veery fun

Our guided tour took us to the witches market and I can't say it's my kind of place. I appreciate different traditions but seeing Llama fetus' hung all over the different shops and stalls isn't very nice.

Interesting place. I thought it would be a real market but it's just a lot of shops in two/three parallel streets. You can find VERY different things, Each shop has a Bolivian woman as the owner, they are all very friendly and nice! I took a picture of one of them, she smiled so

Tourist novelty market where you can find actual Bolivian witches selling herbs, ointments, special gemstones, Llama fetuses and all kinds of fascinating trinkets as part of their belief in magic. On Sundays some of the stalls are closed. Worth taking a walk through if you're in

The witche's market is a street including some boutiques where you can buy weird stuff to do magic. It's nice to see and you don't have to plan a lot of time to go there. But it's worth it just to see the dead llamas. It's taking you out of your comfort zone.
A place that could look only for tourist but indeed still used by local people to find all what is necessary for ancient magician rituals.
Great stuff very quircky place but a must to visit, you can walk along the streets and find clothes, jewerly and lot of weird things you will never see in Europe.

I've heard so many people rave about this street and completely understand why! Although the dead animals and abundance of other things make this street a cool stop. This street plays a huge part in the Bolivian culture. Many of the herbs, candies and other items sold are used

There are more tourist shops here than the ones selling the witch stuff. Some of the latter opens late in the day and in the evening. The selection of goods in the witch shops varies from the more curious stuff - like sacred wood to use for offering - to the more obscure and

Walking through a few shops on this street is something that can only be done here. It's helpful to go with a walking tour or read about things first to know what you are seeing. But there a many things in each small shop - llama fetuses, alters, candies for alters, coca,
This is a good place to visit last before you head home from South America. Its souvenirs are by far the cheapest of the Andean countries with plenty of variety. Haggling is OK.

In the shadow of the Catholic church is the mercado de las brujas. Lots of alpaca, woven goods, souvenirs and prices vary. The brujerias, witchcraft shops, are fascinating. Everything from remedies for arthritis or for the lovelorn, to ritual offerings to the pacha mama are for

Tge witchcraft stuff didn't really work that much for me. It's a bit creepy - selling dry lama fetuses next to coca-cola, pringles and lama sweaters. Worth a stroll as you'll probably be accommodated in the area but don't plan on spending too much time on it.

This would be pretty cool if it were set apart from the rest of the street stalls and kiosks in La Paz, but like many other reviewers have said, it's really nothing special and you will easily miss it if you aren't looking closely. The llama fetuses are a little creepy, and some
It's a good place to buy travel gifts. I also went to Uyuni and other places but the prices here were better.

We went to this place after visiting Moon Valley. The shops are pretty identical in terms of the stuff they are selling. If you wish to come and take a look only, don't come on holidays as most of the shops are closed. There are some souvenir shops and cafes nearby.

A few llama fetuses, some dried herbs and cacti on the sidewalk, and a sign above a kiosk were the only distinguishing marks of the Witches' Market from the rest of the many souvenir shops. Nothing interested me and I was on my way in three minutes or so.

Its a good place to go and meet. Its like a big street market with a lot of local store selling clothes and Bolivian souvenirs. Its a free tour and you can buy lot of stuff over there. Usually you can bargain.

this place has changed a lot since i first went in 2008.... there are a lot more ponchos and general tourist tat than before but it doesnt mean you cant still get down to the base roots of the place. you can have your coca leaves read or just sit down and talk about the exotic

Honestly I was kind of unimpressed here. Maybe we weren’t in the main part of it but I felt it was rather small and really the only thing that stood out that made us realize it was the witches market was the dried hanging baby llama fetusus. Outside of that there wasn’t a ton to
I was surprised by the little shops selling everything for good luck or whatever you need help with. There are places where they can read your future on coca leafs. Artisan shops. Enjoyed the visit.
It's only a few stalls and the owners aren't polite at all. It's worth going because they have a handful of strange things, but don't expect to spend longer than 45 minutes looking around.
An exceptional experience - both for believers and non-believers. It says a lot about the culture and heritage of Quechua Indians. Uncommon attraction in the heart of modern metropolis of La Paz.

The mercado de la hechicera, witch market, is not a whole huge market, but only a few stands on the street with esoteric products for health for people who believe in witch craft or homoopathy medicine. Anyways, it's worth a visit to see all the dead lama embryos hanging around
It was a great place to buy weapons of destruction. I found all the things I need to take over the world. Great place overall.
The headline says everything ... nothing really Special there, can skip this for sure if you do not want to buy some crazy bolivian souvenirs which have nothing to do with Bolivia

Yes this is definitely a touristy place. However, if you look carefully beside the funky and really touristy stuff you can find some real gems. We were warned to be careful for pickpockets and other annoyances. However in the 4 days that we spent in La Paz, before leaving for
Thirty years ago this was an interesting market. Now it is a pathetic tourist draw for anyone interested in kitch.

I looked at the street signs and looked at the map again, but I still wasn't sure I was in the right place. Mercado makes me think of a big market, but the place marked on the map as "Mercado de las Brujas" was only a couple stores selling mostly incense and charms.

Seeing the various dried animals was not my taste and there is definitely a touristy feel to the area. It really isn't much different than the rest of the area around Sagarnaga, but you might as well experience it while you are in the area.
our hotel was just in this area so we have had the chance to pass through this market several times. suggestive and mysterious

This is one touristy place for sure. Beware of pickpockets as review mention that this place was not so safe at all. Most of the shops sell identical stuff. Its good to walk around and take a look, ask for price before purchasing. Difficult to bargain whenever fancy. Sell werid
Unlike anywhere else. Great fun, lots to look at and all sorts of souvenirs (if you want to take them home!) that you could imagine. Lots of places to get an excellent hot chocolate.

You'll see things that you have no idea could be sold. Some is just down right disgusting like dead animals but it is interesting and provides for a fun afternoon. There are potions, dead frogs, powders for good luck, fertility. The dried lama fetus are maybe too much but it is

Such a fun place to walk through. You can purchase really weird things such as mummified baby llamas and various herbs. I felt safe walking through at night. I would recommend against bringing a stroller/wheelchair. The roads are uneven and broken throughout this street.
Ok, so once you get over the llama fetus this basically is yet another tourist market, but very quiet the day we went. Sales staff not that happy, collectively!
It was great to be there but maybe we;ve been to a lot of places like this already! It;s good experience though!
Most of the reviews for the Witches Market are under "Calle Sagarnaga". This is definitely a great experience and a must! It has all the old culture from Bolivia along with the tourist shops!
1. don't miss the graffiti on the walls. They can be very beautiful. 2. it felt safe walking during the day. 3. uphill walk can sometimes be tiring if you had just stepped off the plane

Went there hoping to find some interesting items. Place was packed with locsls.i really stood out and like a fool I stayed. Felt something tickle top of my head and when I looked up they grabbed my passport from my pocket. Avoid any crowded place in Bolivia crime rate is

Do you want a ring, a hammock, a t-shirt, some trousers, some lotions or potions? it's all here if you have the time to root around. It is very close to the main street and there are enough different stalls to while away a couple of hours. It might be best if you have a clear
Interesting to visit. But even better if a local can explain what all the dead baby animals, potions, stones & Artifac are for. Otherwise it is hard to get a good understanding/gauge.

Anyone going to La Paz should try to see the witches market. It is an unusual place that makes it interesting. Weird, colorful display of voodoo stuff for sale from anything to charm a lover or cure a serious ailment. Whatever your heart desires is here.....as long as you

I was expecting more as I'd heard so much about the markets. They're strewn along the streets where traffic still drives past, rather than in a big segregated area, so is very crowded and a bit crazy. The stalls themselves are great, everything you'd ever want to buy and some

- Lets just say I have never been to a market just like this one! Despite the high altitude in this country, i truly enjoyed walking around market. Everything you can find here are pretty much sovenirs but there are some shops that sell really weird and wonderful things that

The witches market is on Melchor Jimenez, a little off Linares, behind San Francisco Church. It is a fascinating place to wander. Some of the things on sale look a bit gruesome and animal lovers may get a bit upset. The most popular item for sale is Llama foetuses. They are
I liked the proximity of Witches market to La Casona Boutique Hotel - It's mostly one street with shops and outside street stalls selling unusual wares. Good to visit.

My rating is based on the fact that I hate shopping, especially when things look the same from one store to the next. That said, if you are interested in seeing some creepy things like Llama fetuses (naturally aborted fetuses) which are used as ceremonial sacrifices for some of
Is amazing, u can find everytingh, and la bolivianita is the best store there, people is friendly and you learn a lot of bolivian culture, and it is ok if you want to take pictures

While in La Paz, I definitely recommend walking through this market at night. If you know Spanish, it is interesting to ask the shop owners the functions of different items such as dehydrated llama fetuses.

Coco leaves, llama fetuses, potions, etc. an interesting place to spend an hour or two. Thought that the llama fetuses would be an interesting piece but definitely didnt want to encourage or support that market.

It’s not really much of a spectacle… just more shops and street stalls, but if you look closely you will find some unusual pieces, presumably used in the making of spells. Llama foetuses are also on display in many of the shops and stalls (see my photos). Potions and drugs are

Whether you are looking for typical handicrafts or original solutions for different ailments, this is the place to go! Remember that prices are not holy here, and don't hesitate to negotiate, especially if you are buying more than one item.

Not as big as I thought it would be but still large considering you've got some very steep roads at high altitude to navigate. You can buy a cure for anything in the world and see some strange stuff like lamas heads for sale. A must see in La Paz.
if you really want to explore any of those interesting markets in Bolivia, you need days... so many things you have never seen there, and so little time. you better speak spanish!

Is a bit hectic but fun, and u an find pretty much whatever u need to good prices, all it takes is patians and time. Even if u dont want to bye anything it still a pretty fun place to just walk trough.

We came here expecting a lot more market stalls than what there was. There was only about 3 shops/stalls open on the day selling traditional potions, etc and a couple selling the typical touristy stuff. Don't wait to buy all your take home gifts from here as you will go fairly

I expected more from this attraction. I have visited far more interesting markets selling 'potions' elsewhere in the world, especially in Africa. The llama foetuses are interesting, but there is not much else. It is generally similar to markets and stalls in nearby streets in La

While I didn't have a problem with the witches market, it wasn't as cool as the guidebooks had made it sound. It was actually pretty small - only a couple of places along one street. The street is in a touristy area near lots of hostels, so it was convenient to get to. I would

Stroll up hill from the San Francisco Church a few streets and the shops that just sell hats, jewellery and jumpers to tourists but witches goodies like the llama foetuses as well. It probably won't take more than 15 minutes to take it all in. Shop keepers are a bit grumpy as

Unless you are looking for a musical instrument, or just want to satiate your curiosity as to what shrivelled llama foetuses and Aymara amulets look like, this so called tourist attraction is really overrated. In fact, along the length of the street, there are only a few shops

The so called Witches Market is made up of a couple of stalls on a street in the old part of town. There are no witches in sight and I would not have bothered or realized it is the "Witches Market" if the tour guide had not pointed it out.

Yes, there are more Gringos here than Bolivians but it is a fascinating place and in my opinion a must to visit when in La Paz. Great area to buy presents to take home and there are also some very good quality artisan items if you search for them, often off the main street, in

Yes, this is the place to come for little souvenirs. There are all manner of little trinkets designed for tourists. Some interesting things, and some not so much. And likewise, you will see plenty of tourists walking down the market street.. But, it's not all bad. It also

We stayed at the hostel: La Posada de La Abuela Abdulia in the middle of the witches market. Frankly I am glad that we stayed in this area because La Paz doesn't have a lot of nightlife going on and out of all the places we visited in the city there were always a few bars open

The famous La Paz Witches’ Market was a 15 minute walk from our hotel, The Rosario. For fans of the macabre the market sells a bizarre assortment of goods, including dried llama foetus which, if buried under the entrance to a home, brings the occupier good luck. A tempting

Fairly near the bus station and near the major hostels so likely that you will come across it staying in La Paz. The market is full of tat for gringos but at either end go and see the crazy ladies with Llama foetuses (people bury them under their house for good luck).
google: If you come to Bolivia and you are looking for souvenirs, this is the place to be. You can find from traditional instruments to clothing made out of alpaca wool (it's soft and warm and you would be crazy not to buy something. Prices can range anywhere from 5$ for small things up to 50-100$ for the most flashy stuff

English:
It's a popular tourist hotspot in La Paz where many people go to have a look at the age old superstitions and beliefs that certain indigenous groups of Bolivia still believe in. You'll find Llama foetuses being sold here along with …
Awfully crowded and antihigiénic. Also,  ilegal items for sale, based on superstition.

text.quote: Well-known hilltop destination featuring dramatic panoramic views of the city, plus scenic gardens.
trip: the Mirador is right in the middle of the city. I loved, that it's very peaceful here, so you can escape hectic La Paz for a moment. Also, not too much people where there. But you have to do a exhausting walk up there.
It is the place where Tupak Katari (indigenous leader) directed the siege to the city of La Paz in the fight for the liberation of the Spanish yoke in the year of 1781.

Friends told us it was great so we took a taxi out AND.... this is a great place to take panoramic photos of La Pax. Wide angle is best. You might also take them from the teleférico. Killi Killi is often crowded
good view of the city and nice place to sit or take pctures. only reason not 5 stars is we walked there and its a bit of a hoof for basically as good a view as you can get from the mi teleferico...
If you're into sunsets and city views that is the place to be. Very accessible (taxi from centre 10BS, walk 15mins from Plaza del Armas) and offering 360 degree view of La Paz. Worth it!
This place is simple and a great view of La Paz . It is great for photos and has places to sit and relax .

Mirador Killi Killi, named after the bird of prey that roamed this area is the most prominent vantage point above La Paz, the highest capital city in the world and already 3.65 kilometres above sea level. So, it’s high, very high. Take the bus, taxi or walk if you dare. The
Mirador Killi Killi has the most amazing views of La Paz!!! It is amazing watching the Sunset from there.

The mirador is a really nice place to go to if you want to admire the lights of the city at night. As always in Bolivia, be careful when travelling by night. If you don't have a car, I would recommend you to take a taxi. The place is probably also.woth going to during the day,
We had a guide and driver so it easy to get to the viewpoint. You have to deal with some steps but it was easy. There is one guy selling stone carvings. yes, there are bathrooms but you have to pay.

It’s a nice view for sure but it’s painful to get up here in traffic . I would personally stick to the cable cars for the views from the top. The red line for example gets you right to the edge and you can get out and take a look at the scene there

Went up just before sunset and had the most beautiful 360 view of the city. Slightly difficult to reach as we tried walking the first day but ended up going back to our hostel when we realized that we wouldn't make it up the stairs due to the altitude. Went by taxi the next day
Although Mi Teleferico is replacing viewpoints in La Paz, Killi Killi is still a lovely viewpoint in which to relax & enjoy the wonder that is this unique city.
Gorgeous views of all parts of the city. Photo opportunities galore. If you're fortunate you'll be able to catch a back view of snow covered local mountains.
Starts on a tough uphill walk ( you can touch the road by putting your hand out in front of you) but the views at the top are worth the walk up!

It is a really great place, especially at nights; it is like seeing a sky with many stars above the same sky. It is really easy to get there, just take the Bus at The Obelisco Square with a sign written with "Villa Pabon". Finally, I think is a really good place to take photo,

From here in pretty much all directions (may be except for one likely to the north) are just "breathtaking views": those of the city below (with some great-looking clusters of like 20-to-30-storied high-rises) and those of the surrounding mountains beyond the city (including the

You can get some panoramic views of the city here. It's not the most beautiful spot itself but good exercise to get up to ( but definitely doable) and you could easily bring a bite and appreciate the views

Killi Killi is in the top of a central hill, where you can see both canyons of the forming city of La Paz, descending from the Andes Royal Range. The place is a bit left, with not an easy access, but worth doing it
Amazing views just a little bit dodge at night time so be careful, seems to be a popular place for people to go drinking at night
From this point, you get a 270-degree view of La Paz settled in the valley surrounded by mountains. A good spot for artists as well as a tourist photographer.

Take about 3-4 hours and walk up to the Mirador Killi Killi . It was quite a walk but worth it . When you get to the top you have a birds eye view 360 degrees of the entire La Paz city , Illimani and other mountains . I suggest taking a picnic up there or a book and relaxing .
Nothing like a good lookout to know geographically how the city works. The view of this viewpoint is splendid.
Best view of the city - free entrance. Take a taxi and tell them to wait (not many taxis there) The view is absolutely stunning.
Made the trek up here and was rewarded with fantastic photographs. Small park to entertain the kids while we gazed at the views.
Just a short walk fro the main area. It is wordless the view . A nice slice of la Paz around you . Worth it
Great spot to go and take pictures, go at sunset. Free to get in, taxi cost hardly anything or ride the cable cars.

I climbed up on feet - it's quite steep! Once you are on top, you have a great view of the valley of La Paz up to El Alto. The mirador itself is nothing special. It's gardens are nice, there is a lot of 'basura' thrown down from the mirador - as everywhere in the city. It is a
In these days you will see much more by taking the Teleférico, but the place is still worth visiting as it is just a short walk away from the touristic center of town.
Lovely look out point with snow capped mountains in the distance which allows you to try and get this whole city in one panoramic shot.
You can easily do that by walking from the CBD. Nice lookout with view over the whole la paz. Do it during the night to see all city lights
It's great to see all of La Paz from this vantage point. So many buildings crammed into this city. The colours were really nice and seeing it in the evening with all the twinkling lights was magical.
We took a taxi here (only 20 BOBs one way). The views of the city are beautiful. We got here just before sunset and it was cold, so bring a jacket!
It's a hard climb to the top but it is worth it! The view is great and the pictures come out amazing with the sunset.
Start your day here. you will LaPaz from a bird's eye view. Has nice terrace. A good place to take pano pictures

Definitely a challenging climb up steep streets if you choose to walk there like I did, but worth the effort for the best views of the city. Full 360 view with the picturesque snow-capped mountains in the background. Don’t leave La Paz without visiting!
We walked like it is typicall for La Paz...up, up and down, and up but it is definitly worth it. The view is fantastic and you can get an imagine how big und crowded the city is. And it is for free.
You don’t need a long time at Killi Killi but make it at sunset. Amazing 360 degree views of the city.

Yes you can catch the cable cars and see the city but this was much more satisfying! Amazing 360 views when you reach the top completely out of breath... well worth it! But not for anyone having issues with altitude... very steep to get up the last bit, but you could always

Since Mi Teleferico offers some of the best views of La Paz from all possible sides, this Mirador lost its position as the best location to see the downtown La Paz. This is still a fantastic location with little tourist. If you are up for a little ( max 20 min) hike you will be

We took a taxi to the top of Mirador Killi Killi as it would be quite a hike otherwise. Our taxi driver was happy to wait at the top and allowed us 20+ minutes to take photos. The views from the top are absolutely worth the trip!
The view point is very beautiful, allowing you to see the city of La Paz from above and the mountains around it
We had a nice time at the view point. I would be aware of your surroundings. We did not have any problems but a few travelers we met did.
Beautiful views all around! Not much to do downtown La Paz hence we suggest you to go climb those stairs. Those houses built on mountains look fantastic from the mirador.
Well worth a trip to Mirador Killi Killi for beautiful panoramic views over the city of La Paz, including an aerial view of the highest national football stadium in the world!

Excellent look-out point for views in many directions of the canyon city, la Paz. On a clear day you can see for many kilometers. Near the street entrance there are public toilets - a small fee is charged for use.

Walked up from Sopocachi district in 25 minutes, but would take most almost twice that. A little confusing to find but map and friendly locals helped. Liberates people - while I was there, four Japanese girls were up on the wall dancing to Spanish music while they're friend
the most amazing and breathtaking views from la paz make sure you go for the sunset and moonrise and take jacket
Quick free destination to see the city with a 360 degree view. Great place for pictures. Taxi up as roads are steep
come to see the city from above. check opening times too. we spent 15 minutes admiring the views from this park.
This spot is well worth your time to get to. The taxi drivers all know how to get there and it gives you a great view of the whole valley from the main plaza to the view of Illimani.

It's a hilltop in the middle of La Paz, easily walkable from downtown. I watched the sunset on New Year's Eve (2017) here and it was beautiful. Lots of couples here taking walks, and local children play in the small playground near the entrance. The arch structure makes for
Ten minute walk from San Francisco church, great location to take pictures of the city, beautiful sunset.
just a must do, the you will understand a little about la paz location, geography, etc. almost 270 view. clean, easy to reach by car. interesting.
This is a great place to really have a good look at La Paz. From this point you can view the entire city and the snow capped mountains in the distance.
If walking around the city pop this on your route, the panoramic views are great and definitely worth a quick visit. It’s up a steep hill (as most good vantage points are) but worth it.
Stunning views of the surrounding area and most of La Paz with lots of seating to take a rest.Truly a great photo opportunity as well!
My hostel was located only 15 minutes away from this viewpoint, but the view at the top made the upward walk worth it! Gorgeous place to see La Paz from a height.
La Paz is the world's highest altitude city at 3600m average but flat on the centre and with mountains up to 4000m and the bottom down to 3000m You can see it all from here - the highs and lows.
Killi killi lookout was the last stop on our private tour in Bolivia The view from the top was spectacular 360 degrees of la Paz city. We were very pleased we went to kill killi !!!

It is quite an effort uphill, be warned. Seeing the city up high is great but the best part was the mountains, both the snow covered peaks if it's not too cloudy and the beautiful red hills just beyond the city
UNIVERSE! Beautiful view, awesome feeling! We own the world and its in front of us! Amazing! One you are there, you feel this ENERGY!

The only place I went to in La Paz that allowed me to take in the sheer vastness and beauty of this city. The light at night emitted like veins and corridors connecting the city together. Very memorable experience. Maybe not the safest at night for the weary. It can be
This place offers an amazing view of the city and it is very fast to get in there using the Teleferico.

Taking a taxi to the top of the hill and then walking up the stairs is the way to go if you want to visit. The views are unusually good from many different angles and it's great for taking pictures. La Paz is a gorgeous city surrounded by mountains. Bring your camera! There

Quite a great escape from busy La Paz! But you are well advices to take a cap or Bus up the hill since it can be quite a hard walk due to the altitude. There is a clean public bathroom right in front and the entrance to the mirador is free of charge. It can be quite cold when

There are a few spots around La Paz that overlook the city centre and thus offer amazing views, but Mirador Killi Killi definitely has the most sweeping vista to see. Might be an idea to take a taxi up to the viewpoint if you have any mobility challenges as the approaching
About a 30 minute uphill walk from the centre, the mirador is worth a visit if just to put your altitude adjustment to the test! The views of la paz, el alto and illimani are worth the hike up
If you want a fantastic view of La Paz, this is almost the best lookout point in the city. In particular, come here for the sunset.

Visited early July 2017 as part of a city tour solely for me. Fortunately, despite it being winter, the weather was bright and sunny and so I was able to take photos of the vista from all angles. Ten minutes is long enough.
Awesome circular views of the city and the snow topped mountains. Safe area. Taxi's are cheap. Do not miss it.

Fantastic views. Take your time, to take it all in. A guide told me it got its name because an eagle had a nest there when they went to build the lookout, and the noise that's made when they grab their prey sounds like "killi killi".

I have lived my whole life in La Paz and didn't know it existed. But since then I can't stop going in the morning for a good coffee and landscape, afternoon for relaxing or just sunset for admiring! If you visit La Paz, make sure you go this wonderful place, has almost 360° of
Great 1st day in La Paz activity to test our acclimatization skills. Short distance from main action but feels worlds away. Love the view and great photo ops!

What a beautiful and queit spot with stunning views. Also good for a short hang out from the bustling city environment. Surpisingly only a few people there and we felt safe (been there during the day). It's also a good opportunity to stroll through up there even it's a bit

Being La Paz set in a valley surrounded by mountains, the best way to see the city is from above and El mirador Killy Killy is easy accessible and have views to the most important landmarks in the city. I don't rate La Paz that much but it is a good way to orientate yourself and

It's quite the 'hike' up to the top of La Paz, but the views of the city and Illimani are incredible. The area at the top has several tiers and there is a nice man that creates some hand-carved stone figurines who hangs out there regularly. It was the best location to see the
Beutiful views of La Paz. It's centrally located so you can get there for the quick pictures and keep exploring.
With almost 360 degree view of the city. Its crazy how many people live in this town. It explains the bad traffic. Its free and a good stopping spot for pictures
A MUST in La Paz!! One of the best lookout in the city. U can see whole city from a platform. 20 minut walk from St. Francis church.
Awesome spot to take in all the city. You can see the whole valley with the Illimani at the back. Be sure to make this stop part of your visit to the city!

We walked from Plaza Murillo to there, was around 30 minutes, slow walk, keep going up till Avenida Sucre, then up following the direction on the map. It offers a good view of the city, if is a sunny day you will get great pictures. If you have a map it will be easy to get there.

It's quite easy to get there with a micro (also the cheapest option), great views of the extended city and the city centre, and a very pleasant walk down hill towards the centre. Go to shoot some pictures and get a drink and enjoy the view.

We originally planned to go to Mirador Laikakota, but that seemed poorly maintained and not that great. So we went to killi killi around the corner instead. Incredible views and a great platform! A must when in La paz!

The Mirador Killi Killi is easy to be reach by taxi and offers a unique view of the city. Also the panorama photos taken there are amazing. Young people still can climb by foot, but seniors should take a taxi driver, who knows where is the mirador...I choose the wrong one, but
20 minute ride out of the center, you can walk up if your in good condicion. Nice spot, but look out for faulse guides and picpockets
If you are passing by, it's worth a quick little walk to check out the views. Don't worry if ya miss it though.

One can reach this high lookout point in La Paz by various means of transport but getting there by foot is a pleasant challenge. Recommended though after a few days in the city. Beautiful views in all directions but in particular when the Illimani is seen
This mirador offers unobstructed views of La Paz and also some decent bathroom facilities. It's in the shape of a semi-circle, which will enchant selfie aficionados.
A very peaceful place, with great views. It's a hike to the top, but well worth it. Or catch a cab ;)

It's a lot of fun to take a cable car with the locals to see La Paz from the altitude of 4000 m but the best panoramic view opens from the Mirador Killi Killi. Advantages: no queues to get on a cable car. You can walk to the place or to take a taxi. Bear in mind that the last
Great location to view this mountainous city. Not to miss. We arrive at sunset and must be a perfect time to see the city in shades.
I simply walked from the old historical center to the mirador, such a great walk, and such a breathtaking view. and it's free!!!!
Wonderful views at a decent little park. It's a tough walk up, but actually pretty fun because you see a typical neighborhood and the views along the way.
The mountain has spectacular views of the modern city with its mountainous backdrop. Good for a birds eye view of la paz. Highly recommended.

We did it the easy way and we got to Killi Killi by car, at the beginning of our tour of the city. La Paz is located like in a cup, with the city center at the bottom of a cup and then houses that seem to be getting up on the mountains surrounding on all sides. From Killi Killi
Loved this little viewing point located a ways from the city center. Worth a trip if you have an hour or so to burn. The most interesting way to get here is on foot but a taxi is a bit easier.

Killi Killi is right in the middle of the city. Excellent for taking pictures, early morning or sunsets. You can have almost 360º views of La Paz. You can walk up the hill, but it's better to take any public transportation.
That's ok to walk a little to have a different view from La Paz. You can walk to this place taking around 20 minutes by foot from the Iglesia de San Francisco.
You have the most amazing view of the city and can take great pictures! And on the way there you can see the city and the life of Bolivians with their interesting and differnt shops and groceries...
Nice place to go. We walk from Plaza Mayor (marcado lanza), it's not very far but it's a uphill walk, so if you are in good shape, it's not a problem to walk there, or take the taxi (it's cheap)
It doesn't look like much from down below but hike up or take a taxi and you will be glad you did. You will see the valleys of LaPaz and get a much better sense of the city layout and size.
The views are very nice and the locations of Killi Killi its more center in the city. Great to take a lot of pictures and have a better idea of the city and the Alto.

Good short trip located somewhat close to La Paz´ center. Take a bus up there because there is no footpath and it is real steep. One has a great overview over the lengthy city shape and the surrounding mountains. It is for free, too ;)

This lookout was just a short walk from my hotel, mind you it was uphill a lot, but you get used to hills when you are in Boliva, don't you? It was in a safe neighbourhood and free to enter and take photographs.

Although we enjoyed the beautiful views from the lookout point, it was difficult to ignore the many stray dogs that inhabit the area and the strong urine smells from those who mistake the area as a public urinal. This is not a spot to enjoy a picnic lunch. We recommend taking a

From central (for instance the catedral) it's only a 25 minute walk or less, and the hill is quite short, so no real need to take a taxi like most suggest unless you don't like walking and have a hotel / hostal in sopocachi or something. It's a nice view, and good for if you

I walked from sopocachi my third day in La Paz. Things in the valley can appear deceptively close on maps, so remember the hills. If you're not acostumed to the altitude, take a cab as this is quite the hike. However, great 360 degree views of the city that left me more
we visited Mirador Killi Killi as part of the city bus tour, the guide was friendly and pointed out points of interest. The views from this point are priceless and a must see!
We visited this lookout on a city tour and it gives a view across most of the old city. Well worth the stop.

It was one of the stops of our city tour.The view of the city is magnificent, there are benches where you can sit and admire the scenery. Wear good walking shoes, sunscreen, hat and bring along a camera to take with you unforgettable memories.A must visit place in La Paz.

We stopped off as part of a morning tour and was definitely worth a look with stunning views across La Paz. As the story goes this is where the indigenous fought off 10,000 attacking spaniards back in the day. Great view of the football stadium as well.

After driving to many small places and looking at different sights, it is best to take a breather and pause to enjoy the view of the city. Love how I was able to just sit, look and admire how lucky I am to be blessed to visit Bolivia. Love to see how the city comes together. Not

A great place to go and enjoy a picnic lunch (tienda's nearby will sell snacks and sodas) We recommend getting a nice take out lunch from the City Centre and spending an hour at Killi Killi enjoying the unparalleled views and photo opportunities. Remember to bring a blanket,

Since we were some of the lucky few, the altitude didn't affect us much. So the small set of stairs you need to walk to the top weren't that bad. Mirador Killi Killi is easily accessible by taxi, and is free of charge to visit! At the top, there was a mariachi band playing and
The walk to this place is a little steep, but definitely worth the effort to get one of the best views of the city. With the mountain in the background, this place is simply wonderful.

One of my favorite places to have a landscape look of La Paz. I've taken different travelers and all enjoy the views. It is easy for me to show them where are the main things or buildings. Just make sure to go during day time as night can get a bit shady.
It's very easy to get there, either walking or by public transportation. A peaceful place with an amazing view. Good for taking pictures or just to sit and relax.
At first I didn't really want to climb all the way up, but I had some free time so I did. And I'm truly glad for that because this view is breathtaking. Even better than the Teleferico!
For just a small walk you are overly rewarded by the view. It's s no brainer really. It's stupid to go to la Paz and not climb up to see the view from here. Absolutely amazing!
Stunning panoramic views of the city. Well worth the steep walk up there. Not much else going on so only need to allow an hour or so.

Of course, you should be extremely careful to go to Mirador Killi Killi at night, however, it gives you a awesome night view of the city of La Paz. It looks like so many stars fallen to the earth around the mirador.. I recommend that you should talk with a taxi driver for the
.... but this City offers tremendous views from many different places and although I enjoyed the Mirador, when I stepped on the teleferique I was taken apart from the magical views.
You can see how big La Paz really is. Go when the sunrises or sets to het the best pictures of La Paz. If you go at night be aware of the couples.
The city is extremely crowded with traffic stopped up all around the emission is so strong and along with the altitude you wonder why so many live here. The view is good but overwhelming
Went as a part of an 11 day tour. Great lookout over La Paz, gives great perspective over the hectic pace of street level.

The lookout point and view is incredible, but if you have young children the park in this location is a must-see attraction. ITs very big with many sections for both young and older children. best park in La Paz

Don't miss this view point. You'll get a 360° view of the city and great pictures. After taking pictures from El Alto, this is a must see. Take a micro from Calle Yanacocha and Comercio to "Villa Pabón" and ask the driver to take you to Mirador Killi Killi.
Pretty sight, but dangerous if a woman goes alone as me, the persons follow you and one spends a very ugly moment, in this zone they steal from him very much the tourists.
Killi Killi offers a nice view of the central area of La Paz, but I prefer the cable car. It's also a nice stroll back to the central area from here.

With the sun at your back, a morning time visit to this scenic lookout is worth the time. I took a cab up to the entrance from the Hotel Rosario and spent a half-hour framing various shots with my camera. A walk down the hill to Plaza Murillo and Calle Jaen made for a nice

Killa Killi viewpoint (kestrels) is a good spot for great photos overlooking La Paz. You not only get the city spread out below you, but you have good terrain and mountain shots as well. You can also take photos of La Paz's fascinating aerial gondola "subway" that leads from
Excellent views of the city and mountains from this viewpoint, visit on a sunny day. These is some walking and steps to get to the area, but not too much.
You have a very good overlooking of the city in each direction, but only in plane you can see the whole city

Nice place to get views of the sprawling city of La Paz & its surrounding snow capped mountains. The sunset light hitting the mountains was beautiful. We came about 20min before sunset and it was worth it. But we'd recommend coming a bit earlier than the scheduled sunset time
Be sure to go here isn't the time & at night both experiences will amazing. Feels as though you're standing in mid-air. BRING YOUR CAMERA

Its quite easy to get there via public transportation, taxi or even just by walking. Its a perfect spot for amazing pictures. I also dont think you need a tour to visit this site. Its very easy to get there on your own.
I went to this place walking from the Murillo square! You can also take a taxi for 8 bolivians from Murillo Square or by bus. The views are amazing! You can take cool pics in this spot!
You must as any where here for the city view. The view is pretty. Lots of locals around.You can visit on your city tour.

I went to El Mirador Killi Killi on Oct. 8th, 2015. It was a wonderful experience. You can see the Ilimani Mountain but most of all, the whole city of La Paz. If you want to take pictures of the Illimani, I will recommend you to go to Calle Camacho.
A great place to get a 360 degree view of the city of La Paz. Just remember that you are at 13000 feet, so I suggest taking an inexpensive taxi to the top.

Took a cheap cab ride to Mirador Killi Killi, and received a beautiful view of the city. Went in the evening time, best time for photos because there's less glare off the buildings. Due to the steep roads in La Paz, best to cab up, but walk back down. I think the only viewpoint
Views of La Paz at most viewpoints are a worth it but seeing as Mirador Killi Killi is only a short walk away from the centre it would be rude not to have a look.
Is easy to walk to from the Cathederal Plaza and gives a great view of the city from both sides of the mountain.
Nice overview of the city. If you can go near the sunset, that would be nice. We took a bus to go there and after that went to see Plaza Murillo. Very nice combination.

Great place to take photos and observe the city from a strange vantage point you fell like in the middle of the city, on a hill top with a 360 degree view its pretty cool and unique, on a sunny day try to avoid sunburn with a hat but it can also be windy.
It's another point of view on La Paz. You nhave to pay to access the mirador (10 Bs). Nice view, but windy
The Walk To The Mirador was a great fun. The view from the top was amazing. We even stayed an hour and played cards up there.

This lookout point has a small playground at it for children and benches to sit and enjoy the view. It's located right near the center of historical La Paz, so you are given a great view of El Alto, the historic downtown, and out toward suburbs.
Don't miss going to this place if you are in La Paz. It has the most complete view of the city and the beautiful mountains around it.

- Free admission. Who needs to visit Empire State Building when you have the best view in La Paz right at your doorstep free of charge! - The very important tip is take it easy when walking up to this amazing scenic lookout. - Bring bottled water and wear a good pair of

Really worth it to spend an hour or more on the hike up here, it's just around 1,5 km from the city center but yes, it's uphill. So take it easy and slow and you will really enjoy the result when you get to the top. Amazing views of all the town of La Paz!
You understand from here how big is the city. It worth a visit and reaching it by foot is a great satisfaction

This is maybe the main public balcony where you can see a beautifull landscape. The downtown, Miraflores Neighborhood, South area, the mountains, the Teleferico, El Alto city... you will be able to see the city as if you were flying. You must take your camera!

Although you will not be able to see the whole city, you will see a great view of a part of it. Security guard gives the impression of a secure site. Lots of people come to see the city from this point, but its not crowded and you can enjoy the view without big noise.
If you come here at sunset, you might end with some good timelapses of the city. The view is quite nice and wide. The downside is that at night the neighborhood is not really welcoming.
Well worth the trouble. The view of La Paz is great. I took a few panoramas and they have come out well. The 360* view of the city shows how big it is.

It had a nice view of Valle de Luna (Valley of the Moon) and better picture taking opportunity than the Teleferico. If you're in the area and have a couple dollars to spare on a taxi ride up, then it's worth a visit. Otherwise, I wouldn't go out of my way for this.

The way up there leads you through the local markets what is pretty cool ... on our way to the stadium we crossed the view point where you have nice sights of the skyline and the sourounding, did not get up there but from the streets you have a nice view too

Its super windy up there however nothing can beats the spectacular view 360 degree around it. Grab a taxi up instead of walking up because its gotten be painful as its upslope. You can view almost the whole vastness of La Paz city and cant keep your eyes away from it. Enjoy the

Though it can be challenging to find if you aren't a local the mirador offers spectacular views of La Paz, including the stadium and Illimani. On clear days Sierra Potosi is visible, there is currently no charge to visit.
Great photo ops of La Paz and unique landscape that reminded me of our South Dakota Badlands. I visited this site while on a group tour.

It's a bit a pain to get to, but once you've arrived this vista gives you tremendous 360 degree views of the vastness that is La Paz, as well as the surrounding volcanoes and mountains. You cannot help admire the size of Bolovia's primary capital city from this vantage and we

It was nice to have a 360 view of the city from above, however the area is not nice and there isn't anything else to do around there- So if you want a coffee, or a bite to eat there is nothing around, toilets are not clean either and since is not close to anything go prepared- I
Fantastic view to the city but it´s a tough job to climb up there.. make sure you are use to the altitude first :)

We tried looking at La Paz from many viewpoints and in my opinion, this was the best. There's nothing there except the view, but given that it was free (at least for us, though we went on New Years and it looked like they may have just been letting people enter freely as an
is an ideal place to see the city center from up high. It is very quiet, not to much people, excelent spot for a nice sunset

i reccomend taking a taxi if not part of a regular city tour. streets in the are are noy very well marked and no sign refers to the "mirador". no matter weather conditions the view is very much impressive and it is good to kill sometime in the city after visiting some other

The iconic photo of LA Paz has the mountain and the football stadium in the foreground. Killi Killi is the best place for this photo. It also provides great views over the city. My advice is to get a radio taxi there and soak it up, before walking back towards plaza San

Grab the bus for El Pabon on Ayacucho street. The view is impressive in all directions. A good place just to sit quietly and appreciate the Andes. When I was there, one guy was teaching songs to another on pan flutes, made for a nice background. Walk back down using the

If you take the city tour bus (central route), they will stop there for about 10 minutes so you can soak in the view and take photos. Combine this with a ride up the yellow cableway and you have seen all of La Paz.

I like to take panoramas in the uprising and also in the sunset, if you want to see how drastic looks LP, it's the perfect point of view, one of my favorites, also to take a friend on the first days in LP.

Is a steep walk - but worth it for the views. Take 30 mins from San Francisco church. We ran this each morning during our week in La Paz. It's safe, clean & a nice place to visit with outstanding views of La Paz!
google: A fantastic spot in La Paz. It offers a nicest view from the city and it is closer to the Central Park. You can go walking.
Really wonderful views, especially considering how easy it was to reach—only a 20 minute walk from the hostel I was staying in. A number of locals enjoying the day as well.
Beautiful spot with great views over La Paz! We walked up, it was alright if you took it slowly. Nothing for the altitude sick one though. ;)
Super cool place to have a great view
Stunning view. I recommand visit after sunset.
Amazing views, and safe to go at night. Take the orange line and get off at the last station. A cab from there should be 15 bolivianos.
If you're into sunsets and city views that is the place to be. Very accessible (taxi from centre 10BS, walk 15mins from Plaza del Armas) and offering 360 degree view of La Paz. Worth it!
Great panoramic view over the city. It is easy to go to the closest teleferico station and then get a quick taxi for 5-10BS if you don’t have much time.
I can see the whole view in the middle

An easy-ish climb up to give you a great view around the city and a quick way to help you get familiar with La Paz. It's amazing to see how the city stretches up all sides of the hills/mountains. Well worth a trip to the top.
Best way to see the beauty of the city, plus I've heard there are plans for a calisthenics park over there so that should bring even more traffic to the area

The walk up was steep but shorter than I expected. The view was gorgeous! Really wish the public bathrooms were open though. The police were around in their office right next to the bathrooms but they didn't care much about anyone.
Awesome view of the down town of La Paz city, for knowing the caracteristic of the city

Its a rally nice view on the city. Its a good location not.far from the city center. But at the same time its not so easy to get it. You can take a taxi o go by feet all the way up because its not easy to understand the public …

The amazing views are worth the steep hike to the top! Visit in evening during sunset and stay till the city lights up! You get the 360 deg panoramic views and the added bonus is to see snow capped andes on one side! That's the prettiest site!
Stunning views of the city from here. Enjoyed watching the sunset from here and city lights turn on. Lots of uphill roads trying to get there though which was also a fun adventure.
Nice view on La Paz. It is an easy walking distance up the hill.
Good views, but very poorly organized and in the middle of a not very nice neighborhood. Better to enjoy the views from the Teleférico!
Amazing view! Definitely worth a visit!
This place ha e an awesome view of LA Paz.
Fabulous views, well worth the effort of but steep but short climb up
On this mirador, you will have a good view on the whole city, you can clearly see the mountains and how the city is organized

I heard about this spot by a tour guide born in La Paz, however, it was not featured in my lonely planet book. The march up to Killi Killi is definitely worth it, although one might find oneself walking through an empty and a little  scary …
Good place. If you stay in the center of the city you can go there walking

No matter whether you're a local or a visitor, this place is a must-see tourist attraction. Wanna have the best shots of the city? Come here! Wanna enjoy some me time and just think? This is the right spot.
Absolutely beautiful! Worth the steep climb, especially on a good day! The best Panoramic view of La Paz you will get. Better than the cable cars.
Beautiful place to admire La Paz. It's easy to get there and near city
Nice place to have overview of La Paz and take pictures
The way up is steep but short. The view totally worthy.
Nice views of the city and mountains/volcanos in the back. Pretty chilly up top depending on the weather so dress accordingly.
Great views of city and Illimani
A must visit in La Paz. Nice view of the mountains, stadium and total city. To reach there it’s bit steep. Best time to visit is early mornings or just before sunset.
Decent viewpoint of the city, including the stadium and a nice panaromic setting.
Beautiful view!
I'm from La Paz and this is one of the best and prettiest view point of the city, definitely recommend and Worth the trip
Beautiful view of the whole of La Paz. Very relaxing as well. Bring a picnic and enjoy the view.
Oh yes it's best place for see beauty of lapaz city. Mostly in night.
It's a hike to get here but the views will stay with you for a long time to come!
High pt in the city. A bit of a hike and you can get winded but you can't beat the views.
free, nice view and the acess is possible by car
So strategic with amazing views!
Marvelous view of the city at night. Take a taxi/Uber here.

It has an incredible view from the city of La Paz, from one side you can see old downtown with all the historical buildings, in the other side you can see Miraflores, all the buildings and the stadium, a place that is worth to pay a visit.

Well worth a visit to this Mirador, the views are spectacular and for once, it's not an expensive tourist trap! 

When we went (at about midday) there were very view people so we had plenty of time to take some fantastic photos. 

Great view of La Paz!
A very nice view of the wonder city and it's not so far from the middle of the city.
Terrific view, decent uphill walk to get there (your heart will beat quickly with the altitude).
